prompt: <description>Part 1: Construction of a Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism Step 1: Sketch the Base of the Prism Create a new coordinate system. On the XY plane (face_1), construct a loop consisting of four straight lines. * line\\_1: Starting at (0,0), end at (0.75,0). * line\\_2: Starting at (0.75,0), end at (0.75,0.6923). * line\\_3: Starting at (0.75,0.6923), end at (0,0.6923). * line\\_4: Starting at (0,0.6923), end at (0,0). The loop formed should be clockwise when viewed from the positive Z-axis. This ensures the correct orientation of the prism. Step 2: Scale the Sketch Scale the sketch uniformly by a factor of 0.75. This scaling operation is crucial for accurately defining the dimensions of the prism. Step 3: Generate a 3D Sketch from the Scaled 2D Sketch Perform a 3D translation using the translation vector (0,0,0). Rotate the sketch about the Z-axis by an angle of 0°, the Y-axis by 0°, and the X-axis by 0°, using Euler angles. These rotations define the orientation of the sketch within the coordinate system. Step 4: Extrude the Sketch to Create a 3D Model Extrude the 2D sketch vertically by a distance of 0.0288 units along the positive Z-axis, giving the prism its height. The height, width, and length of the prism, as defined in the description, should match the specified values closely. Part 2: Cutting a Square Out of the Rectangular Prism Step 1: Create a New Coordinate System and Sketch Face Create a new coordinate system, translated from the previous one. The translation vector should be (0.2019, 0.5192, 0). The Euler angles for this coordinate system are (0°, 0°, 180°). The rotation about the Z-axis by 180° is necessary to ensure the proper positioning of the sketch with respect to the existing prism. On the XY plane (face_1), construct a loop consisting of four straight lines. This loop will form a square. * line\\_1: Starting at (0,0), end at (0.3462,0). * line\\_2: Starting at (0.3462,0), end at (0.3462,0.3462). * line\\_3: Starting at (0.3462,0.3462), end at (0,0.3462). * line\\_4: Starting at (0,0.3462), end at (0,0). Step 2: Scale the Sketch Scale the sketch uniformly by a factor of 0.3462. Just like in Part 1, this scaling operation is key to achieving the required dimensions of the square. Step 3: Generate a 3D Sketch from the Scaled 2D Sketch Translate the sketch by the translation vector (0,0,0) for proper placement during the intersection with the rectangular prism. Use Euler angles (0°, 0°, 180°) for orientation purposes. Step 4: Perform a Cut Feature Boolean Operation Extrude the 2D square sketch vertically by a distance of 0.0288 units along the negative Z-axis, performing a cut operation on the existing rectangular prism. The result will be a rectangular frame with a square cutout in the center.</description>
